Dear Adam Baker:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
THIS REPORT CONTAINS QUOTED PROFANITY AND/OR SEXUALLY EXPLICIT
LANGUAGE
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000992
Special Investigation Intake Date: 09/03/2025
License #: CP820201497
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling
Chief Administrator: Adam Baker
Agency Name: WAYNE COUNTY DHHS - WESTERN
Agency Address: 27540 MICHIGAN AVE
INKSTER, MI 48141-2202
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 11/22/2025
II. METHODOLOGY

1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 8/29/25, during a parenting visit, the foster care supervisor
became upset and cut the visit short. The foster care supervisor
called the respondent parent derogatory names during the
incident. The foster care supervisor then grabbed the youth out of
the parent's arms and threw the youth on the ground from a height
of 5'7." The youth landed on their head on a concrete floor.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Parent A was interviewed by phone on 9/5/2025. He began the
conversation by stating he wanted his case transferred to a
different agency, but that isn’t happening. He stated his parenting
time has been cancelled per court orders because he has made
his children anxious about their clothing, which he feels is
ridiculous. He stated, on 8/29/2025, he was on a Facetime call
with Parent B during her parenting time during which he heard
Foster Care Supervisor call Parent B “weird bitch.” He stated he
heard the phone fall and “a lot of commotion” before the phone
hung up. He stated Parent B told him she had to push Foster Care
Supervisor off of her and Foster Care Supervisor tried to snatch
Youth A from Parent B causing Youth A to fall on the ground.
Parent A was asked specifically about the allegation Youth A was
dropped on the ground by Foster Care Supervisor causing him to
hit his head on a concrete floor. Parent A responded by stating
that was his understanding of what happened. He stated the
agency is trying to cover it up by stating it’s not on video.
Parent B was interviewed by phone on 9/5/2025. She began the
interview by stating she wanted her case moved to a different
agency, closer to her home. She stated she has been asking for
this for a long time, but the case has not yet been moved. When
asked about the allegations, Parent B reported she had parenting
time scheduled with her children last Friday, 8/29/2025, at the
agency office. She reported arriving 15 or 16 minutes late. She
walked in, gave her kids hugs and waters then sat down on the
couch. She stated one of her sons became sad and asked Parent
B if she could call his dad, Parent A. Parent B reported she had a
visit the previous Tuesday during which the person who was
2

supervising that visit, Supportive Visitation Worker, allowed her to
call Parent A. Parent B stated she was using her phone to record
her son running and Foster Care Supervisor got mad and told
Parent B she could not be on her phone during visits. Parent B
asked Foster Care Supervisor if there was a court order stating
she could not be on her phone. Parent B stated she then called
Parent A via facetime at which time Foster Care Supervisor ended
the visit. Parent B stated Foster Care Supervisor told her to “stop
being weird” then stated “you’re really weird. You’re a weird bitch.
You only act like this around your kids.” Parent B stated she was
holding Youth A on her stomach near the doorway inside of the
visit room and Foster Care Supervisor “snatched” Youth A from
Parent B and “sat him down super hard.” Parent B stated Foster
Care Supervisor did not drop Youth A as was alleged, but he
started to cry when she sat him down. Parent B stated she walked
out of the visit room and left the building after this happened.
Parent B was asked if Youth A had been dropped on his head on
a concrete floor from over 5 feet, to which she stated the person
she was talking to when she reported the allegation kept asking
her for a height Youth A was dropped from, but she wasn’t sure.
She added she tried to call back the next day and “withdraw” the
allegation stating it should not be investigated. When asked why,
she stated Program Manager told her the incident was not on
video, so there was no proof it happened. When asked to again
describe what happened, Parent B stated she stepped out of the
visit room, into the hallway, to see if security was coming. She
stated the kids were standing near Foster Care Supervisor at the
time. Parent B stepped back into the room, and as she was
hugging/holding Youth A near her stomach, Foster Care
Supervisor grabbed him, forcefully setting him down on his feet.
She stated Youth A is not a steady walker yet, so when Parent B
sets him down on his feet, she does it gently by sliding him down
her body. When Foster Care Supervisor did it, she set him down
roughly, so he lost his balance and fell back hitting his head.
Parent B stated she knows where all of the cameras are in that
room and there were no cameras pointing at them when this
happened. She stated there should be a moment prior to her
leaving when she and her kids cannot be seen on camera. She
stated she immediately left after the incident.
Parent B stated Foster Care Supervisor was calling her names
throughout the visit. She also stated Foster Care Supervisor gave
Parent B Uber gift cards but snatched them back out of her hand,
telling Parent B to sign a form.
3

Parent B reported Program Manager is saying Parent B
threatened to hit or hurt Foster Care Supervisor, but she didn’t.
She stated she told Program Manager she feels like Foster Care
Supervisor wants someone to put their hands on her. Parent B
stated she told Program Manager it would be wrong of her to put
her hands on Foster Care Supervisor like Foster Care Supervisor
put her hands on Youth A. She stated she apologized to Program
Manager for the situation during their conversation. Parent B
ended the interview by stating “I genuinely just want to be moved
away from her” referring to Foster Care Supervisor.
After the phone interview, Parent B sent text messages including
two videos taken at the end of the visit during which Parent B is
repeatedly asking Foster Care Supervisor to say why the visit is
being ended. Parent B also sent a photo of Youth A sitting on
couch with a circle drawn around the upper right front of his
forehead. Multiple text messages were exchanged to seek
clarification as Parent A wrote that the photo was of Youth A’s
injury; however, the photo was taken while Youth A was on the
couch in the visit room and Parent B had not previously reported
that Youth A sustained an injury. Parent B responded the photo
was a screenshot taken from a video she had taken of Youth A’s
injury at the beginning of the visit. After the text exchange a call
was made to Parent B as the messages were increasingly
confusing. When asked how she took a video of Youth A’s injury
at the beginning of the visit when the alleged incident occurred at
the end of the visit which Parent B previously reported she
immediately left after, Parent B replied, “my bad the picture shows
where the injury would have been.” Parent B was reminded of the
allegation that Youth A fell back after being set down, to which she
stated he “kind of fell sideways so the injury was near the
front/side.”
Youth B was interviewed by phone on 9/5/2025. A few minutes
after Parent B’s phone interview concluded, she called back
stating she was with Youth B for parenting time and wanted him
interviewed as he heard and saw everything that has occurred
with Foster Care Supervisor on 8/28/2025. Despite attempts to
suggest she focused on parenting time; she insisted and put him
on the phone. Youth B reported he recalls the visit with Parent B
being ended early by Foster Care Supervisor the previous Friday.
He stated he never heard Foster Care Supervisor swear at Parent
B or call Parent B by any name. He stated he never saw Foster
Care Supervisor touch or grab Youth A. He denied seeing Youth A
being dropped or falling over or hitting his head during that visit.
The call ended at that time; however, Parent B called again after
4

her parenting time stating her son wasn’t comfortable telling the
truth because the person supervising the visit was looking at him
while he was talking.
Program Manager was interviewed via video conferencing on
9/5/2025. She reported on 8/22/2025 she met with Parent A and
Parent B in person to explain that the court ordered Parent A’s
visits to be suspended. On 8/26/2025 Parent B had scheduled
parenting time which was supervised by Supportive Visitation
Worker. Program Manager was told that, during the visit, Parent B
told the Supportive Visitation Worker that Program Manager had
given her permission to Facetime Parent A during the visit.
Program Manager stated she spoke with Foster Care Supervisor
on 8/27/2025 about this having occurred so Foster Care
Supervisor knew it was not allowed. On 8/29/2025, Foster Care
Supervisor was supervising Parent B’s visit during which she
began to Facetime with Parent A. Foster Care Supervisor ended
the visit as this was not allowed. Program Manager stated she
was in the building during the visit but was not in the visit room
area until after Parent B had left. When she arrived Foster Care
Supervisor had Parent B’s 5 children with her in the agency office.
Program Manager stated she watched the kids while Foster Care
Supervisor and another staff member put car seats in the car for
the youths to be transported back to their foster homes. During
this time, Program Manager was holding Youth A, and he was
observed to be in good spirits. Program Manager did not see any
injuries on Youth A. Program Manager stated Parent A was irate
that Parent B’s visit ended early and texted Program Manager at
4:53pm stating that Foster Care Supervisor put her hands on
Youth A and he wasn’t leaving until the police arrived. Program
Manager stated the police never arrived or spoke to anyone at the
office.
Program Manager stated she watched the video footage from the
8/29/2025 visit on 9/2/225. At that time, she only watched the
ending of the visit where Foster Care Supervisor was alleged to
have put her hands on Youth A. Program Manager stated Foster
Care Supervisor was not seen touching Youth A at any point prior
to or immediately following Parent B leaving the visit. On 9/3/2025,
Program Manager watched the video footage of the entire
8/29/2025 visit as she had spoken to Parent B who said Foster
Care Supervisor snatched something out of her hands during the
visit. Program Manager stated the video shows Foster Care
Worker approaching Parent B at 4:42pm with gifts cards in one
hand and a form in the other. Parent B is seen trying to take the
gift cards, but Foster Care Supervisor pulled her hand back.
5

Parent A then signed the form after which Foster Care Supervisor
handed her the gift cards. A minute later, Foster Care Supervisor
went to the visit room door, holding it open. She stated Parent B is
seen walking through the door, presumably leaving the building.
Foster Care Supervisor walked back into the visit room then left
with the youths through a different door in the room which exits
into the agency offices. Program Manager stated Foster Crae
Supervisor is never seen picking up, holding, setting down, or
dropping any of the youths.
On 9/2/2025 Parent B called Program Manager, but Program
Manager’s schedule did not allow her to return the call that day.
On 9/3/2025 Program Manager called Parent B after watching the
video. Parent B told her at that time she had been calling people
all day trying to get her case moved to a different agency, stating
she never liked Foster Care Supervisor. Program Manager stated
she could hear Parent A in the background throughout the call.
This is when Parent B first told Program Manager that Foster Care
Supervisor “snatched” Youth A out of Parent B’s hands. Parent B
stated the police were called after that happened. Program
Manager told Parent B she wasn’t aware of the police being called
as they had not contacted anyone at the office. Program Manager
told Parent B she had watched the video footage from the visit
room and did not see what Parent B alleged. Parent B then made
several statements about hurting Foster Care Supervisor the next
time she saw her. Program Manager heard Parent A also making
threats in the background at which point Program Manager stated
she was not going to continue the call and Parent B hung up.
Program Manager stated she filed a police report and a
department incident report regarding the threats the parents made
toward Foster Care Supervisor during the call.
Program Manager stated Parent A and Parent B called her
multiple times after that call, but she did not call them back until
she was able to have someone else present to witness the
discussion. She reported calling Parent B on 9/4/2025 at 12:19pm
while Program Manager 2 was present and taking notes. She
stated Parent A was somber at the time and seemed remorseful.
She stated she could hear Parent A in the background and Parent
B asked Program Manager if she was available to talk at 2:00pm.
When Program Manager stated she was not, Parent B stated she
did not want to talk at the time. Program Manager said it seemed
like Parent B moved away from Parent A as he could no longer be
heard in the background at which time Parent B stated she would
never hurt Foster Care Supervisor or anyone else. Parent B stated
she never had a problem with Foster Care Supervisor. Parent B
6

said she was afraid the case was going backward, and she was
afraid Foster Care Supervisor was going to “report this stuff at
court.” She stated she didn’t know why her visit ended early on
8/29/2025. Program Manager explained to her the visit was ended
because she called Parent A on Facetime when it had previously
been explained to her his visits were suspended by the court and
she was not allowed to Facetime him during her visits. Program
Manager reiterated to Parent B that Parent A was to have no
contact with the youths. Parent B then stated something about
“stuff” being snatched from her hand by Foster Care Supervisor
during the visit. Program Manager told Parent B what she saw on
video regarding the gift cards. Parent B stated she doesn’t
understand why people keep saying she is lying about things.
Program Manager gave Parent B the example of telling people
Foster Care Supervisor had snatched and hurt Youth A, but that
nothing like that is on video. Parent B then apologized and stated
“it’s fine, whatever. She didn’t do it, but she was loud and rude.”
Parent B then asked Program Manager if she could speak to
Foster Care Supervisor to apologize. Program Manager told
Parent B she could not speak with Foster Care Supervisor due to
the threats she made against her earlier in the week. At that time,
Program Manager again heard Parent A yelling in the background.
Parent B yelled to Parent A “you keep saying that shit that gets
me in trouble.” Parent A was heard yelling that he was coming to
the agency to “fuck shit up” at which time Parent B ended the call.
After the call was ended, Program Manager filed a new police
report about Parent A’s threats.
Program Manager stated she has worked with Foster Care
Supervisor for many years and could not see her swearing at a
parent or calling a parent names even when frustrated.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed by video conferencing
on 8/18/2025. She reported there have been issues with Parent B
Facetiming Parent A during her supervised parenting time over
the past couple of weeks. She stated Parent B had Facetimed
Parent A during her parenting time on 8/19/2025 but the worker
who was supervising did not know. It wasn’t until the youths told
their foster parents that Parent A was on Facetime during the visit
that Foster Care Supervisor found out. The following day,
8/20/2025, Program Manager called Parent B and told her Parent
A was not allowed any contact with the youths, including
Facetime. On 8/26/2025 Supportive Visitation Worker was
supervising Parent B’s parenting time during which Parent B
began Facetiming Parent A. Supportive Visitation Worker told her
she was not allowed to Facetime Parent A, but Parent B told her
7

Program Manager gave her permission to do it, so she continued
the Facetime call. On 8/29/2025 Foster Care Supervisor was
supervising Parent B’s parenting time. Foster Care Supervisor
stated she thought she saw Parent B Facetiming and asked
Parent B what she was doing to which she replied she was taking
video of Youth A walking. Foster Care Supervisor stated she
believed her as Youth A has recently started to walk, but then
Foster Care Supervisor heard Parent A’s voice coming through
the phone. Foster Care Supervisor told Parent B she knows she is
not supposed to be Facetiming Parent A to which Parent B
responded Program Manager told her it was ok to do so. Foster
Care Supervisor told Parent B she knew that wasn’t true at which
time Parent B became upset and confrontational. Foster Care
Supervisor stated a building staff member came in and told her
Parent A was there wanting to talk to Foster Care Supervisor, but
Foster Care Supervisor said he did not have an appointment to
meet with her, and she was busy supervising a visit. Foster Care
Supervisor then heard Parent A yelling at her through Parent B’s
phone. Foster Care Supervisor told Parent A his interaction with
her was inappropriate and that he had to leave the building.
Parent B became verbally hostile so Foster Care Supervisor told
her the visit would end. Parent B began recording Foster Care
Supervisor with her phone and kept asking Foster Care
Supervisor to say why the visit was being ended. Foster Care
Supervisor called security a couple of times, but they never came.
She was at the visitation room door, holding it open and the
youths were all on the couch at the opposite end of the room.
Parent B approached Foster Care Supervisor, still recording her
before leaving. Foster Care Supervisor left with the children
through a different door which is only accessible to staff. Foster
Care Supervisor stated as she was getting the youths ready to
leave, she received a text message from either Parent A or Parent
B stating the police were called because Foster Care Supervisor
put her hands on Youth A.
Foster Care Supervisor stated Parent B did not hug or hold any of
the youths before she walked through the door to leave. Foster
Care Supervisor stated she did not pick up, grab, hold, or drop
Youth A at any point during the visit. She stated the only time she
touched him was when she was putting him in the car seat to
leave.
Foster Care Supervisor stated she heard Parent B accused her of
taking gift cards out of her hand. Foster Care Supervisor stated
Parent B is given $200 in Uber gift cards every Friday for
transportation to the next week’s visits. Each week, Parent B signs
8

a form when she is given the gift cards. Parent B was upset at the
time and was saying she was not coming to anymore visits if
Foster Care Supervisor would be there, so Foster Care Supervisor
asked Parent B if she wanted the cards. Parent B tried to grab the
cards out of Foster Care Supervisor’s hand, so Foster Care
Supervisor pulled her hand back and said, “come on, just sign the
slip” to which Parent B responded, “you’re weird.” Foster Care
Supervisor stated she said, “you’re being weird,” in response,
which she regrets saying. Parent B then signed the paper and
Foster Care Supervisor gave her the gift cards. Foster Care
Supervisor denied swearing at Parent B at any point during their
interaction. She stated she does not know how long Parent A was
on Facetime or what he could hear. She added it was her
testimony that resulted in Parent A’s visits being suspended so he
held her personally responsible.
VIDEO FOOTAGE REVIEWED
On 9/9/2025 video footage was reviewed via video conferencing
with Program Manager. The video was date stamped 8/29/2025
and appears to be of a visitation room.
• 4:13pm Foster Care Supervisor was in the upper right
corner of the video at a table on which a laptop and other
items are placed. Five youths were playing, one of them
being Youth A.
• Foster Care Supervisor left the room with two of the youths
then returned with the youths and Parent B. Parent B sat
down on a couch located on the opposite side of the room
from Foster Care Supervisor. Parent B had Youth A on her
lap.
• 4:33pm Parent A was talking to someone on her phone via
Facetime. The camera was situated above and behind her
so her screen could be clearly seen. Program Manager
identified the person on the phone screen as Parent A.
• Parent B stood up and pointed her phone toward Youth A
as he walked.
• 4:37pm Program Manager was sitting at the table in the
upper right corner of the video screen talking to Parent B
who was again seated on the couch at the bottom of the
video screen, continuing to Facetime.
• At 4:41pm Foster Care Supervisor stood up and started
packing up her belongings. She walked over to Parent B
with what Program Manager identified as gift cards in her
9

right hand and a piece of paper in her left hand. Parent B
reached for the gift cards and Foster Care Supervisor
pulled her right hand back quickly. Parent B signed the
paper in Foster Care Supervisor’s left hand after which she
handed Parent B the gift cards. At that point, Parent B
began recording Foster Care Supervisor with her phone.
• Foster Care Supervisor walked to the door near the upper
left/middle of the screen where Parent B previously
entered. The door and the area surrounding the door were
clearly seen on the video footage.
• Foster Care Supervisor stood in the doorway holding the
door open.
• Parent B approached Foster Care Supervisor, recording
her with her phone and talking to Foster Care Supervisor.
None of the youths were near Foster Care Supervisor or
Parent B.
• 4:43pm Foster Care Supervisor walked out of the room
through the open door and Parent B followed her. The
youths were not near either Parent B or Foster Care
Supervisor.
• Foster Care Supervisor re-entered the visit room without
Parent B, walked to a door at the bottom right of the screen
and walked out with the youths following her. Youth A is the
last youth seen walking out of the room, on his own, at
4:45pm
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
Court Order dated 7/9/2025 stating the following:
• Parenting time with Parent A, even if supervised, may be
harmful to the children.
• Parenting time of Parent A is suspended.
• The therapist report indicates visits with Parent A are doing
harm to the children’s mental health and should be
suspended.
• Based on testimony of the worker about the trauma to the
children prior to visits and the therapist report Parent A’s
visits are hereby suspended.
Foster Care Supportive Visitation Weekly Progress report written
by Supportive Visitation Worker on 8/29/2025 stating:
10

• Parent B told Supportive Visitation Worker she had a
meeting with an MDHHS Supervisor who told her she was
allowed to Facetime Parent A during her visits to allow him
to communicate with the children briefly at the beginning
and end of the visits.
• Supportive Visitation Worker told Parent B that following
the 8/19/2025 visit, Program Manager communicated to
Supportive Visitation Worker that Parent B was not allowed
to Facetime during her visits.
• Parent B appeared frustrated regarding the redirection of
Facetiming and told Supportive Visitation Worker she would
like to be assigned to a different worker.
Portions of a Text Message Exchange with Parent B on 9/5/2024:
• From Parent B - Photo of Youth A with a circle drawn
around the left side of his forehead.
• From Parent B – That’s the mark
• To Parent B – When was the photo taken of the mark?
• From Parent B – This is from Friday videos and that picture
of his mark.
• To Parent B – Sorry, you were already partway out of the
room and leaving at the time she snatched the baby and
sat him on the ground causing him to fall back. This looks
like he is in the room on the couch, and the mark is on the
front, so I just want to make sure I understand at what point
during the visit the photo was taken.
• From Parent B – I have him on the couch because it was a
video I just zoomed in on my video.
• From Parent B – The mark it’s like towards the front side.
• From Parent B – My baby has a lot of hair.
• To Parent B – Ok, so after she sat him on the ground and
he fell, you went back into the room and put him on the
couch?
• From Parent B – I had him in the couch with me –
Recording his mark.
• To Parent B – Do you have time for another call because
my understanding is she snatched your son from you as
you were hugging him on your way out of the visit room to
leave.
11

• From Parent B – In the beginning of me recording them first
two videos in the blind spot of the door.
Email from Program Manager 2 to Program Manager documenting
the 9/4/2025 phone conversation with Parent B. The notes were
consistent with what Program Manager reported was said during
the conversation, including the following:
• Program Manager informed Parent B that she watched the
video two times and Foster Care Supervisor never had
Youth A in her arms. At this time Parent B stated,
"whatever it does not matter". Program Manager reported it
does matter because these are serious allegations. Parent
B then stated, "that is fine, she did not do it, but she was
verbally loud and rude." Parent B stated again that this did
not occur.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance regarding Foster Care
Supervisor demonstrating suitable character and ability to provide
for the needs of youths and families as the video footage refutes
Parent A’s allegations as Foster Care Supervisor is never seen
touching, grabbing, picking up, setting down, or dropping Youth A
at any point during Parent B’s visit. Contrary to Parent B’s
allegations, there is no area near the visit room door that is not in
view of the camera. Additionally, while Foster Care Supervisor did
pull her hand back when Parent B attempted to take gift cards
from her hand she did not grab anything out of Parent B’s hand.
Finally, while Foster Care Supervisor stated she did say “you’re
being weird” to Parent B there is no evidence to support Parent
B’s allegations that Foster Care Supervisor swore at her or called
her names.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
September 29, 2025
______________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 30, 2025

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
13
